nodes.name: Abstraction
nodes.definition: Making one solution work for multiple problems by making it more general

nodes.name: Algorithm
definition: A list of steps to finish a task. A set of instructions that can be done with or without a computer.
For example, a list of steps to make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich is an algorithm.

nodes.name: App
nodes.definition: A type of application software, often meant to run on a mobile device, such as a phone or computer.

nodes.name: Artifact
nodes.definition: Anything created by a human. See computational artifact for the computer science-specific definition.

nodes.name: ASCII
definition: (American Standard Code for Information Interchange) is the way most text files are written on computers and the Internet.
In an ASCII file, each letter, number or special character is represented by a code, a string of seven 0s or 1s (also known as a 7-bit binary number).

nodes.name: Automation
nodes.definition: The process of changing a system or software to allow it to complete their tasks without help from humans.

nodes.name: Backup
nodes.definition: The process of making copies of data or data files to use if the original data or data files are lost or destroyed.

nodes.name: Binary
nodes.definition: Binary is the language computers use. It uses 0’s and 1’s to represent information, like letters and numbers.

nodes.name: Bits
nodes.definition: Stands for binary digits. The smallest unit used to measure computer data.

nodes.name: Block-based programming language
definition: Any programming language that lets users make programs by dragging and dropping blocks, instead of writing code using text.
(Also known as visual coding, drag and drop programming, or graphical programming blocks)

nodes.name: Bug
definition: An error in a software program.
It can cause a program to stop working or act in a way it is not supposed to. Removing errors (bugs) is called debugging.

nodes.name: Byte
nodes.definition: 8 bits

nodes.name: Cipher
nodes.definition: A system for encrypting and decrypting data.

nodes.name: Cloud
nodes.definition: Servers that save information. They can be in a different location and are reached using the Internet.

nodes.name: Code
nodes.definition: Any instructions written in a programming language to be given to a computer to follow. See also: program, commands, algorithm

nodes.name: Command
nodes.definition: An instruction for the computer. Algorithms and computer programs are made by putting many commands together.

nodes.name: Computational artifact
nodes.definition: Anything created by a human using computational thinking and a computing device. Examples include an image, audio, video, presentation, or web page file.

nodes.name: Computational models
nodes.definition: Computational modeling is the use of computers to simulate and study difficult systems using math and computer science.

nodes.name: Computational thinking
definition: A way of solving complicated problems and creating solutions that a computer can understand.
Strategies include decomposition (breaking problems into smaller pieces), pattern matching, abstraction
(making changes that allow one solution to work for multiple problems), and algorithms (instructions that a computer can use).

nodes.name: Computer science
nodes.definition: The study of how computers and programs work and how they are created and used.

nodes.name: Conditionals
nodes.definition: A statement that will happen if a specific situation is true. For example, if it is cold outside, you will wear a jacket.

nodes.name: CPU: Stands for “central processing unit”. It is the brain of the computer and can understand binary code. See
nodes.definition: processor

nodes.name: Data
nodes.definition: Information, such as numbers, words and measurements. Computer programs often need data and will also give us data.

nodes.name: Debugging
nodes.definition: Finding and fixing problems (errors/bugs) in programs.

nodes.name: Decode
nodes.definition: The opposite of encode. To convert data back to its original form using a code that is available to the public.

nodes.name: Decompose
nodes.definition: Break a problem down into smaller pieces.

nodes.name: Decryption
definition: The opposite of encryption. To convert data that has been written using a secret key, back to a language we can understand.
The process of changing a coded message back to a language that you or the computer can understand. It is the opposite of encryption, where you are converting information into a code.

nodes.name: Digital divide
nodes.definition: the gap between those who can easily access computers and the Internet, and those who do not.

nodes.name: Encode
definition: To convert messages or information into another form using a code.
This is different from encryption, because this code is available to the public and the goal is to make data easier to work with for computers or humans.

nodes.name: Encryption
definition: To change messages or information into a code. This is different from encode,
because this code is only known by the two groups who have the key; it is used to keep data private.

nodes.name: Event
nodes.definition: An action that causes something to happen.

nodes.name: Execution
nodes.definition: The process of following instructions.

nodes.name: For loop
nodes.definition: Used to run pieces of code over and over again.

nodes.name: Function:
definition: A piece of code that you can easily call over and over again. Each time a function is called,
a specific set of instructions will be followedThis definition differs from that used in math. Also known as a subroutine.

nodes.name: GPS
nodes.definition: Abbreviation for Global Positioning System. GPS is a system that uses satellites in space to find where an object is on Earth.

nodes.name: Hacking
nodes.definition: Using a computer to get data without permission.

nodes.name: Hardware
nodes.definition: The physical parts of a computer, computing system, or computing device.

nodes.name: Hierarchy
nodes.definition: A system where items are ranked by importance.

nodes.name: HTTP
nodes.definition: (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) is the set of rules for moving files (text, images, sound, video, and other files) on the World Wide Web.

nodes.name: HTTPS
nodes.definition: Is the same as HTTP, except more safe. It encrypts and decrypts information, which prevents hackers from stealing it.

nodes.name: Input
nodes.definition: The signals or instructions sent to a computer.

nodes.name: Intercept
nodes.definition: When someone without permission stops data from being transmitted (sent) to its destination.

nodes.name: Internet
nodes.definition: The collection of millions of computers and servers that are connected around the world to share and move information.

nodes.name: Iterative
nodes.definition: Repeating an action to reach a goal, target, or result.

nodes.name: Logic (Boolean)
nodes.definition: A type of algebra where all expressions are true or false. Uses AND, OR, NOT, and other combinations.

nodes.name: Loop
nodes.definition: A set of instructions that repeats while a specific condition is true. For example, for as long as this number is less than 100, add 3 to it.

nodes.name: Looping
nodes.definition: Repetition, using a loop. The action of doing something over and over again.

nodes.name: Lossless
nodes.definition: Making data take up less space without losing information.

nodes.name: Lossy
nodes.definition: Making data take up less space by throwing away information that is not important.

nodes.name: Memory
nodes.definition: Where computing devices store information for a short amount of time (temporary).

nodes.name: Model
nodes.definition: A representation of (some part of) a problem or a system. Note: This definition differs from that used in science.

nodes.name: Nested loop
nodes.definition: A loop that is inside another loop.

nodes.name: Network
nodes.definition: A group of computing devices (personal computers, phones, servers, switches, routers, etc.) connected by cables or wirelessly to share and receive information.

nodes.name: Open source
nodes.definition: A type of free software that is available to everyone. It has code available to the public, so anyone can see how it works and change it to make it work differently.

nodes.name: Operating system (OS)
nodes.definition: Software that a computing device needs to turn on and run. It allows programs to run and works with the hardware. Every desktop computer, tablet, and smartphone has an operating system.

nodes.name: Operation
nodes.definition: An action, resulting from a single instruction that changes the state of data.

nodes.name: Packets
nodes.definition: Small chunks of information that have been made from larger chunks of information.

nodes.name: Pair programming
definition: When two people work together on one computer to code. One person, the driver writes the code,
and the navigator reviews and checks if the code is right. Then, after some time, they switch roles.

nodes.name: Paradigm (programming)
nodes.definition: A group of ideas about how something should be done, made, or thought about.

nodes.name: Parallelism
nodes.definition: When instructions are split up by multiple processors and carried out at the same time. It can make tasks on computing devices finish faster.

nodes.name: Parameter
nodes.definition: Stored names of information that we want to use for a subroutine or function.

nodes.name: Pattern matching
nodes.definition: Finding similarities between things.

nodes.name: Persistence
nodes.definition: Trying again and again, even when something is very hard.

nodes.name: Piracy
nodes.definition: The illegal copying, sharing, or use of software.

nodes.name: Procedure
nodes.definition: Commands for a computer that can be used many times in a program. It can be a  function or a subroutine.

nodes.name: Processor
nodes.definition: The hardware inside a computer or phone that executes a program. The CPU (central processing unit) is similar to the brain of a computer.

nodes.name: Program (n)
nodes.definition: A set of instructions that the computer follows in order to reach a specific goal.

nodes.name: Program (v)
nodes.definition: To create a program.

nodes.name: Programming (v)
nodes.definition: The art of writing, testing, and fixing programs to solve problems.

nodes.name: Protocol
nodes.definition: The special set of rules that end points in a telecommunication connection use when they communicate. Protocols specify interactions between the communicating entities.

nodes.name: Prototype
nodes.definition: A rough draft of a final product or information system.

nodes.name: Pseudocode
nodes.definition: An explanation of the instructions a computer must follow (also known as a computer program or algorithm) in regular words, instead of in programming language.

nodes.name: Remix
nodes.definition: making changes to an existing procedure.

nodes.name: RGB
nodes.definition: (red, green, and blue) A system used to show the colors on computer screens. Using different amounts of red, green, and blue can be used to make any color.

nodes.name: Routing (v)
nodes.definition: Finding paths that exist between different things in a topology.

nodes.name: Router (n)
nodes.definition: A special type of computer that decides which data link a packet needs to be sent over next.

nodes.name: Run program
nodes.definition: Cause the computer to follow the commands written in a set of instructions to reach a specific goal.

nodes.name: Security
nodes.definition: The use of technology to protect and keep computing resources from being entered or changed.

nodes.name: Servers
nodes.definition: Computers that exist only to provide data or processor power to other computers..

nodes.name: Simulate
nodes.definition: To mimic real world actions.

nodes.name: Software
nodes.definition: The instructions, programs or data used to tell computers what to do and how to complete specific jobs.

nodes.name: SMTP
nodes.definition: The rules for sending email messages on the internet.

nodes.name: Storage
nodes.definition: A place (usually a device) where data can be kept, stored and used later, either for a short amount of time or permanently.

nodes.name: String
nodes.definition: A group of letters, numbers, and/or other symbols. A string could be used to stand for a name, address, or song title.

nodes.name: Structure
nodes.definition: A collection of parts.

nodes.name: Switch
nodes.definition: A fast device that receives packets of information and sends them to their final location on a nearby network.

nodes.name: System
nodes.definition: A collection of computing hardware and software that work together to finish shared jobs, for a common goal.

nodes.name: Topology
definition: A special kind of map that focuses on showing the connections that exist between different things.
For example, an internet topology would look at how different computers are connected together with data links.

nodes.name: Troubleshooting
nodes.definition: To find where a problem is within a computer system or software, and solve it.

nodes.name: User
nodes.definition: A person that a hardware or software product is designed for.

nodes.name: Variable
nodes.definition: A placeholder name that represents pieces of information, such as numbers and words. The value that the name points to can change.

nodes.name: Wearable computing
nodes.definition: Miniature electronic devices that are worn under, with or on top of clothing.
